poem:
I barrel through midnight avenues under a sickly neon glow,  
my steel ribs rattling secrets in the hush between stops.  
I do not pause for possums—  
they curve their whiskered backs in pleading silhouettes,  
but my oath is welded in iron and diesel:  
no creature stalls the pulse of Route 21.

I spin tall tales into my horn’s guttural blast:  
how once I swallowed a streetcar whole,  
how the underpass breathes steam that tastes of old regrets,  
how the farebox hums like a shrine,  
coins melting to molten truths beneath my heel.  
In each window’s reflection I see passengers  
with hollowed eyes and prayers pinned to their coats,  
clutching their hopes like litter drifting in a storm drain.

The city arcs beneath me—  
an azimuth of cracked pavement and flickering signs—  
I ferry lost souls to corners stitched shut by memory.  
Stoplights blink in bruised Morse code,  
names etched in concrete, unclaimed.  
The rails hum a litany of law and order,  
my manifesto coded in every bolt.

I drive on, a relentless pulse through the urban dark,  
spinning myth into metal,  
refusing mercy to possums,  
cursing the night by sheer will alone.
